Award.AwardTitle: High-Resolution Secondary Ion Mass Spectrometry for Chemically Imaging Cell Membrane Organization
Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program, Prof. Mary Kraft and her group at the University of Illinois are developing a new approach to chemical imaging of organized structures like membranes using high-resolution secondary ion mass spectrometry. The work entails development and optimization of functionalized protein-specific affinity labels, metabolic labeling strategies, cell preservation protocols, and statistical methods to evaluate component co-localization. The method will significantly impact our understanding of how plasma membrane organization affects cellular function, and the molecular interactions that produce this organization.

The project will provide interdisciplinary training of graduate students. Other educational activities focus on promoting the professional development of K-12 math and science teachers and educating middle and high school students about the chemical interactions that drive biological membrane organization. Results will be incorporated into laboratory activities and supplemental teaching materials for middle and high school students that will be provided to teachers through the Nano-CEMMS Center at the University of Illinois.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF-supported project focused on developing a new approach to image the distributions of sphingolipids, cholesterol, and distinct proteins in the plasma membranes of mammalian cells with ≤100-nm-lateral resolution, and to assess co-localization between these components.  To coordinate the interactions between a cell and its surroundings, the plasma membranes of mammalian cells are compartmentalized into domains of differing protein and lipid composition. Plasma membrane organization and membrane-mediated cellular processes are influenced by the cholesterol and sphingolipid levels within mammalian cells. Despite this importance, when we began this research, the distributions of cholesterol and sphingolipids within the plasma membrane could not be imaged without using fluorophores that may alter the molecular interactions and localization of the lipids they label.

We developed a new approach that uses high-resolution secondary ion mass spectrometry (SIMS) to map the distributions of cholesterol and sphingolipids in parallel with protein species of interest in the plasma membrane with ≤100 nm lateral resolution. To enable detection with high-resolution SIMS, we optimized metabolic labeling protocols to selectively incorporate distinct stable isotopes into the cholesterol and sphingolipids within living cells, and developed fluorine-functionalized antibodies to selectively label proteins of interest. We identified a method to preserve the cells without altering plasma membrane organization, and optimized sample preparation to overcome the low sensitivity, and thus, low working lateral resolution, that is typical of cell analysis. Then we showed that the distributions of cholesterol, sphingolipids, and distinct proteins in the plasma membrane could be imaged in parallel with ≤100 nm lateral resolution by mapping the lipid-specific isotope enrichments and protein-specific fluorine signals on cells with high-resolution SIMS. We also developed statistical methods to quantitatively evaluate co-localization between the cholesterol, sphingolipids, and the protein of interest within the plasma membrane.  

This new SIMS imaging methodology enables testing the numerous currently intractable hypotheses that concern the cholesterol and sphingolipid distribution in the plasma membrane, and the effects these distributions on membrane organization and function.  Such work will lead to a better understanding of the mechanisms that module plasma membrane organization function. For example, while developing this approach, we tested two long-standing hypotheses in cell biology: that 1) the plasma membranes of mammalian cells contain cholesterol- and sphingolipid-enriched domains; and 2) the influenza viral envelope protein, hemagglutinin, clusters in sphingolipid- and cholesterol-enriched membrane domains. We found that the plasma membranes of fibroblast cells contain sphingolipid domains, but they are not enriched with cholesterol, which refutes the first hypothesis.  Likewise, the hemagglutinin-rich regions in the plasma membranes of fibroblast cells were not enriched with cholesterol or sphingolipids, which argues against the second hypothesis.  Instead, we discovered that sphingolipid organization in the plasma membrane is dependent on the cytoskeleton. This finding confirms an alternative hypothesis for plasma membrane organization.  Therefore, in addition to advancing the field of analytical chemistry, this NSF-sponsored research has also advanced understanding in biology.
